the details were all kept quiet so everybody wanted to start finding out what the bug actually
was now um in the general case very few organizations install patches really
quickly actually in Germany there's a weird really weird law where Financial institutions are disallowed from
installing patches on critical systems without testing them for at least a week which is a fantastic legislation love
your law um well in the general case the agreement is that not publishing any
information concerning the vulnerability when you releases a patch buys the customer time to install patches this is
the reason why Microsoft wants all the security people that actually give them information about a bug to keep quiet
about it until they have had time to release the patch and install the patch and Microsoft thinks they buying time for their
customers um this comes from the fact that there's an asymmetry between the problem of like reverse engineering
program and just recompiling it making the change in recomp recompiling the is really easy whereas reverse engineering
it is really timec consuming the general assumption is that the reverse engineering has to reanalyze the entire application and then start comparing the
the different functions in order to find out what changed um both software vendors and high level language virus
authors try to exploit this as high level language virus authors want to buy time but like from having
antivirus signatures and so on and having the antivirus team really know what's going on and software vendors
just want to buy time for their customers now diffing executables on an
instruction level is really difficult a very small change in the source can trigger significant changes in the executable adding a structure member
will change all the immediate offsets which deal with that structure if you have a structure of I 16 members and you
add a member in front of it all access to that structure in the binary will change like the the immediate values for
using for addressing the members of the structure will change um adding a few lines of code will have well can have
drastically different register assignments as a result because the compiler will always use what which
register is free and it's when it's compiling and as such if you just change a few things it can lead to being like
completely different registers used throughout the the entire function um other things or another problem is that
many compilers these days or many linkers try to arrange the basic blocks of every function in an optimal way having everything aligned having
everything in place so growing one of those basic blocks can trigger a change throughout the entire binary where all
basic blocks are rearranged and if you're dealing with Microsoft executables they have weird aggressive
runtime Linker optimizing thing they call it um profiling based linking
optimization or whatever ever it's going to be part of Visual Studio 2003 or or four I don't know like the next version
of visual studio is supposed to have it and Microsoft has been using this for a few years where they basically create
profiling information about every basic block in the application and then they know all the regular trodden paths so um
if you have a function or you have an application which has error handlers I mean a significant part of any application is error handlers those will
not be executed all that often so Microsoft takes all the basic blocks which are not executed often and puts
them on a different page than those that are executed often this leads to better performance with uh well due to the
prefetching stuff it definitely leads to a lot better paging behavior of applications because the operating system can page out lots of code Pages
which are not not used all the time now the overwhelming majority of the
instruction changes in a binary are Irrelevant for us as a security analyst because um well we don't care about
immediate Chang INF for structure access and we don't care all that much about a different register being assigned mind
we care about bugs and we care about logic changes so we have to start making a tradeoff um can we risk more well can
we reduce the number of false positives by risking that we have a false negative at

Approach different from many others is you regard a binary as a graph of graphs meaning um we're looking well first of
all we're looking only for changes in program logic we're not looking for constant change or whatever so um we're
looking at the the program as a graph of graphs meaning you have one large graph which contains all the relations the
function have to each other function a calls function B function B calls function C function a can also call
function C that's the large graph now every single function in itself is a graph as well which is the flow graph of
the function which has the all the basic blocks and the if blocks and so on so the program logic is more or less
encoded in these two graphs if you add a single if inside of a function you'll trigger a change in its F graph if you
add or change a function call from string copy to sdn copy you will change the call graph so that the program logic
is more or less encoded in these these other graphs now what I'm doing is I'm trying
to find the changes by comparing the flow graphs only and um this this
actually should detect all logic changes as soon as somebody adds an if he will will be changing a fla graph and I
should see it so in theory this comparison should be false positive free I should only get changes that actually
change the logic of a program because well if somebody just or if the compiler just do does rearrangements he can't
change the logic of the the flow graph too much so um well there should not be
a false positive in reality um there are a few false positives occasionally
because um well some Modern compilers inline entire functions if they feel like it and so on so false positives can
occur but uh there're significantly like there's very few of them um the big
disadvantage of using the graphs only is that the comparison will not be false negative free meaning if somebody just
changes a buffer size or well constant I will not see it because I'm never
looking at any immediates at all I'm just looking at the graphs so um then again um I mean the usual way
that security vulnerabilities are fixed as not by somebody enlarging a buffer if there's insufficient size checking you
